texts.shortText:
The Phylum Chaetognatha comprises only about 70 small, almost entirely planktonic, marine species. The body is elongate and dart-shaped and consists of a head bearing a circle of curved chitinous grasping spines and a pair of dorsal eyes, followed by an elongate trunk bearing one of two pairs of lateral fins and a tail fin.

Most of the commonly encountered coastal species belong to the family Sagittidae, which have two pairs of lateral fins and two rows of teeth. Common regional genera include Parasagitta, Pseudosagitta, Serratosagitta and Mesosagitta, but microscopic examination is required to identify specimens to species level.

Global: Not identified to species, so not possible to state distribution.

Local/Regional: Family found across region.

Although small, chaetognaths can be extremely common in plankton samples and are important predators of smaller planktonic animals, particularly copepods, but also larval fish and other arrow-worms. They are thus an important link in the food chain. They alternately float and swim using dorsoventral undulations of the body to dart forward and then resting with the fins extended. There are no gills and gas exchange is across the body wall.

Voracious feeders, detecting prey from vibrations in the water then darting forward to seize the victim with their grasping spines and injecting it with a bacteria-derived toxin (tetrodotoxin â€“ the same toxin famous for making certain puffer-fish toxic to eat). The prey may be as large as the predator and some chaetognaths have been reported to eat as much as 37% of their own body weight each day!

Chaetognaths are hermaphrodites with internal fertilization via a spermatophore transferred from the donor to recipient, following a short signalling interaction. The eggs are fertilized as they pass out of the oviduct and are usually simply ejected into the water, although in some species they may remain attached to the body surface of the parent for some time. Development is direct into tiny arrow-worms, without a larval stage.
About 30 species are known from South Africa and they need to be examined microscopically to identify them to species level.
